moves.1. d4: For those that know me, this is no suprise........
moves.2. c4 Nf6 3. Nc3: A little unusual. The Leningrad variation 3. g3 g6 4. Bg2 Bg7 is much more common.
moves.3... d6 4. Bg5: Trying to find an early way to further weaken black's kingside. I'm not extremely familiar with the Dutch, so I decided that I should at try to act as if I knew what I was doing:)
moves.4... g6 5. e3 Bg7 6. Bd3 O-O 7. Nge2 Nbd: All logical developing moves by both sides so far....
moves.8... e5: Hoping I'll take so his knight can re-take.
moves.9. f3: Inferior.....my idea was to support a later e4, but I then realized that with black's dark squared bishop and queen still on the board, I had inadvertently opened up a diagonal to my king. Yikes!
moves.12. exf5 gxf5: Now black has an isolated pawn on an already weakened kingside. I just gotta punish this.....
moves.13. Bxf5 h6 14. Bh4: Preserving the pin on black's queen.
moves.14... Rxe3: This take by black was expected. It actually helped my cause, as I can now make a play myself on the e file.
moves.15. Qd2 Re7 16. Nf4: Willing to exchange rooks, while throwing more gas on the fire that is black's weakened kingside.
moves.16... Rxe1+ 17. Rxe1 Bb7 18. Ng6: And I can see a possible mate delivered on h7.
moves.18... Nf8 19. Ne7+ Kh8: 19...Kf7 20. Be6  KxN 21. Bd5  saves the game, but loses the Bb7. The end is now near....
moves.20. Bxf6 Bxf6 21. Qxh6+ Nh7 22. Qxh7#: A pretty little attack. This game reinforced my disdain for playing the Dutch when I have the black pieces, as I am far too conservative defender. Good game ritt:)
